headline: Déjà Vu: House Republican Paul Gosar Was Tied to Yet Another Far-Right Event
author: Caleb Ecarma
sentences:

That said, Gosar hasn’t always tried to distance himself from his apparent ties to the far right.

Last week, the far-right group American Populist Union listed Gosar as a “featured guest” at an April 20 event in Tempe, Arizona—a date that happens to coincide with Adolf Hitler’s birthday, and is celebrated by some white extremists.

But shortly after the Arizona Mirror reported Gosar’s billing at the event, which the House lawmaker had also promoted on his own Instagram account, the Republican’s campaign consultant claimed full ignorance.
In February, the lawmaker appeared in a prerecorded video at the America First Political Action Conference (AFPAC), an event organized by white nationalist influencer Nick Fuentes.
“The only event we have that day is a farm tour.” McShane went on to claim that he “didn’t approve” using Gosar’s Instagram account to promote the ticketed event.
“I never approved this event and have never spoken to this group,” said Gosar campaign consultant Rory McShane in a Thursday statement to The Washington Post.
The two Republicans were since lightly scolded by House minority leader Kevin McCarthy for their “unacceptable” involvement with the conference.
Last June, the lawmaker appeared to defend Fuentes after a flyer surfaced showing Gosar was set to hold a fundraiser with the AFPAC founder.
“It wasn’t supposed to go to Nick’s group,” Gosar said, referencing the video message that was broadcast for AFPAC’s attendees.
Trapeur chalked up Gosar’s apparent change of heart to “a misunderstanding and scheduling conflict” in a statement to The Post.
Arizona conservative representative Paul Gosar is once again attempting to brush off ties to far-right organizations.
This isn’t the first time Gosar has had a run-in with a far-right group that he then said was accidental.
It was an innocent “miscommunication” caused by his “short-handed” staff, he told Politico last week.
(He also told the outlet that the date of the upcoming event is unrelated to Hitler’s birthday.)
The congressman then said the clip was meant to be a general “welcome video” for other groups.
